contentrichtext.text: {{about|the wood rose, a parasitic plant|the sea anemone also called ''Dactylanthus''|Dactylanthus antarcticus}} {{Redirect|Hades flower|Greek mythology|Asphodelus#Mythology}} {{taxobox |image = Dactylanthus taylorii01.jpg | status = NV | status_system = NZTCS | status_ref = <ref name=nzpcn>{{cite web|title=Dactylanthus taylorii|url=http://nzpcn.org.nz/flora_details.asp?ID=122|publisher=New Zealand Plant Conservation Network|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref> | regnum = [[Plant]]ae | unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] | unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] | unranked_ordo = [[Core eudicots]] | ordo = [[Santalales]] | familia = [[Balanophoraceae]] | genus = '''''Dactylanthus''''' | genus_authority = Hook.f. | species = '''''D. taylorii''''' | binomial = ''Dactylanthus taylorii'' | binomial_authority = [[Joseph Dalton Hooker|Hook.f.]] }} '''''Dactylanthus taylorii''''', commonly known as '''wood rose''' or '''Hades flower''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/nature/wildfacts/factfiles/668.shtml |title=Science & Nature - Wildfacts - New Zealand short-tailed bat |publisher=BBC |date=2008-07-25 |accessdate=2011-10-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzes.org.nz/nzje/free_issues/NZJEcol20_1_81.pdf |title=NZJEcol20_1_81.pdf |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref> is a fully [[parasitic]] plant that grows on the roots of certain trees in [[New Zealand]]. The [[host (biology)|host]] tree responds to the presence of ''Dactylanthus'' by forming a burl-like structure that resembles a fluted wooden [[rose]] (hence the common name). [[Māori people|Māori]] names for wood rose are '''''pua o te reinga''''' or '''''pua reinga''''' ("flower of the underworld")<ref name="govt">{{cite web|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/conservation/native-plants/dactylanthus/facts/ |title=Facts: Dactylanthus: Native Plants: Conservation |publisher=Doc.govt.nz |date=2006-09-01 |accessdate=2011-10-20}}</ref> and '''''waewae atua''''', "feet of gods". It is [[monotypic]] to the ''Dactylanthus'' genus. One of its most common host trees is pate or seven-finger (''[[Schefflera digitata]]''). ==Physical description== Plants are either male or female. They flower between January and April and are primarily [[pollination|pollinated]] by the native [[New Zealand Lesser Short-tailed Bat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/casn098.pdf |title=Location of Short-Tailed Bats using Dactylanthus |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-10-20}}</ref> The nectar exudes a musky smell that resembles mammalian [[sweat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/Sfc019.pdf |title=The use of Dactylanthus nectar as a lure for possums and bats |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://scienceblogs.com/tetrapodzoology/2007/04/the_most_terrestrial_of_bats.php |title=The most terrestrial of bats : Tetrapod Zoology |publisher=Scienceblogs.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-29}}</ref> Introduced [[mouse|mice]] and [[rat]]s also pollinate them although rats tend to destroy them. Fruits about {{convert|2|mm|in}} long are produced from February to May.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} The plant has no [[chlorophyll|green]] leaves, and [[root]]s are also absent, the plant being connected to the host by its [[Plant stem|stem]]. Some plants have been aged in excess of 30 years old{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}}. It prefers damp but not waterlogged [[soil]], and is often found at the head of small streams. It tends to live under dense canopies of tall trees but some specimens may be found at forest borders. The plant is [[crypsis|cryptic]], and hence hard to survey, but there are unlikely to be more than a few thousand in existence. Most of these are in the [[North Island]], including [[North Auckland Peninsula|Northland]], [[Coromandel Peninsula]], [[Gisborne, New Zealand|East Coast]] and central regions, but there are a few on [[Little Barrier Island]]. It is likely that many sites are known only to collectors, as the woody growth has commercial value. ==Conservation status== ''Dactylanthus'' is regarded, as of 2004, as a 'Category A' threatened species. The New Zealand Department of Conservation started a recovery plan in 1995. Protection measures include pest control and enclosure of the plants in cages. The wood rose is under threat from harvesting by collectors, browsing by [[possum]]s, rats, [[pig]]s and [[deer]], habitat loss, and the [[Pollinator decline|rarity of its pollinators]] and seed dispersers. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.doc.govt.nz/templates/podcover.aspx?id=33587 Department of Conservation] - wood rose information. [[Category:Santalales]] [[Category:Flora of New Zealand]] [[Category:Endangered flora of New Zealand]] [[Category:Plants described in 1859]]
